comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: After a few red herrings I searched Trove for "Albury Wines Kavanagh", and it came up with an 1881 advert mentioning an address 225 William Street - SMH 10/12/1881 p.12 col.2 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13500948 . But I am having trouble with reconciling the slope of William Street. Help! See also this Henry King photo at full zoom - there's a wholesale and family grocers in roughly the right spot - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362658129/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Michael W. Kavanagh & Co., grocers and wine and spirit merchants, where located in Cowper Street, Waverley (now Randwick) in 1888. I don't think this is their grocery, but advertising for a brand of beer they supplied.

I'm currently cross-referencing Sands entries for grocers, tea merchants, and wine and spirit merchants to see if I can't come up with a shortlist of possibilities ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The only matches I can find for both tea and wine and spirit merchants are - Evans Sons & Co., 137 York Street Stanley and Littlewood, 73 Stanley Street, and 247 George Street 137 York Street is on a corner with a lane ... www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes, M W Kavanagh was one of the red herrings (I wonder if one of these grocers specialized in imported wholesale red herrings?!).

W W Kavanagh seemed right because their advert (see link above) also mentions Albury Wines, Bass & Co.'s Ale, Guinness Stout etc.

It looks like a street corner in the center of 1880s Sydney with fairly grand buildings, especially the one on the right.  York and George are good bets!   Work in progress ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [red faced - slapped by a red herring] One should always look at the links provided ... :)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I'm not quite convinced Kavanagh is a herring...Per the digitised newspapers we can see that he was both a wine and spirit merchant and a grocer (though I can't find a ref to him operating a tea warehouse). Per the digitised newspapers, M.W. Kavanagh of 225 William St transferred his wine and spirit merchant's license to Dorahy Bros in January 1887 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13625718 ...several SMH births notices and the NSW BDMs indicate that this would have been Michael William Kavanagh, who was married to Annie. Kavanagh appears to have moved on from 225 William St at about the time of the license transfer. Probably the best advert which shows that Kavanagh operated as a grocer is the one mentioned by Beachcomber (above), which ran in the SMH during December 1881 (far rhs column, 9th from top)- nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28383386 ...per Beachcomber's observation, note the refs to Bass & Co's Ale, Guinness's Stout, Albury Wines...all up I'd say there's a good chance that this pic involves Kavanagh's premises at 225 William Street...or if not, then I'd say that at the very least it involves an advertisement for Kavanagh's on a wall close by (here keep in mind that the sign doesn't indicate to the passer-by where Kavanagh's is...which would of course have been unnecessary if it were painted on one of Kav's walls). When you look at the pic...well the 'known knowns' are that the street is aligned roughly East-West and there's quite a significant incline towards the rhs (which would fit with parts of William Street as it was in the 1880s)...it's a pity the writing on the sign above the awning (top left) is too small to read at this resolution (hint!)...and you'd like to think that the substantial building on the right would have attracted the occasional photographer or newspaper artist over the years...it looks like a government building, bank, insurance office, etc. It's interesting that there aren't too many hits on the digitised newspapers in the 1880-1890 period for 'Budweiser'...most of the adverts appear in the mid 1880s...talk about coals to Newcastle! Mate! Anyway, wherever it is, this is yet another fantastic pic! I want one of those brooms! You can't buy a decent broom anywhere these days! Hey, their trousers aren't too bad either come to think of it. I could go a pair of well made 'one crown' moleskins.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Hey...that substantial building on the right looks remarkably similar to the part pic of the William Street post office which appears in Max Kelly's 'Faces of the Street' (p. 13)...pellethepoet refers to this fascinating book on another post...unfortunately in this pic the horse and cart carrying muck partly obscure the corner door, which makes it difficult to compare building details with those in the pic in 'Faces of the Street'...but from what I can make out, the only differences of note involve the ornamental work at the top of the door, which might perhaps have been altered over the years...any thoughts?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] By Jove! You've done it quasymody! The Post, Money Order and Telegraph Office and Commonwealth Savings Bank, corner of Rosebank and William Streets. Our old friend James Barnet, architect. The full picture of the detail to which you refer is on page 100. The architectural detail (apart from some embellishments lost over time) and the street incline is a perfect match. And if you go to City of Sydney Archives - photosau.com.au/Cos/scripts/home.asp - and search for "002151", there's our corresponding corner, with a Tea Warehouse sign. So, the pass and set-up goes to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia], but it was [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] who followed through and scored the goal. Looks like all I get credit for is interference! :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] BRILLIANT WORK! Trying to read the street sign (between "GUINNESS'S" and "WHOLESALE", see note) - fairly sure it says "ROSEBANK St". 1895 interactive map (1894 cable tram lines are marked but not evident in this photo) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
And ... not too huge a flight of the imagination to put this other one across the street to the left of this view  ... 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5784088616/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Could be! We'll have to look elsewhere than the William Street book though, as it's only a record of the southern side of the street that was to be demolished for the road widening.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Credit all around!...[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] put me on the track of Kavanagh and got me thinking more about what I assumed was his sign (I gather it was on the side of 217 William St, which was the end building on the next block along from his shop at 225 William St)...[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] put me on to 'Faces of the Street'...Yeah I was in a bit of a rush before and missed the pic of the post office on p. 100. 'Faces of the Street' is a must have reference book for 19th century building spotters! It's absolutely fascinating! Lucky it was in the library near where I hang out.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Great sleuthing everyone! What an interesting conversation!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: For some more views of the Post Office, search for 002135 (this is the picture on p.100 of the 'Faces of the Street' book), 002136, 001448, and 001449 at photosau.com.au/Cos/scripts/home.asp. The latter two photos show the Post Office still hadn't been demolished by 1926.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: These are good! 001449 shows a Willhelm Backhaus poster up on the wall! (maybe not for long by the looks of things) ; here's a nice pic taken during Backhaus' 1930 tour - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn3660494

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Hey! We get another view of the William St Post Office in this 1906 Sydney Mail article on the Ocean Street cable tramway - news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZVZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LJUDA...
